M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: (Breach of Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment – M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

G.L. c. 186.proposition: Defendant Mark Reynolds is, upon information and belief, an individual who owns and/or manages residential rental property located at 123 Ashmont Street, Dorchester, Massachusetts 02124 (the “Premises”), and is a “landlord” within the meaning of Massachusetts landlord–tenant law, including G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 1, 3 and G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19C, because the action concerns the residential rental of real property located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division, and arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 1, 3 and G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19C, because the action concerns the residential rental of real property located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Municipal Court, Dorchester Division, and arises under the laws of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as landlord and owner and/or manager of the Premises, has been responsible for providing and maintaining heat to the Apartment in compliance with Massachusetts law, the State Sanitary Code (105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.), and the covenant of quiet enjoyment implied by G.L. c. 186, § 14.

105 C.M.R. 410.201(A).proposition: Specifically, 105 C.M.R. 410.201(A) requires that the heating system be capable of maintaining a temperature of at least 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m., and at least 64°F at all other hours, from September 15 through June 15 each year.

105 C.M.R. 410.201.proposition: The heating system repeatedly failed to maintain lawful and reasonable indoor temperatures as required by 105 C.M.R. 410.201 and related provisions of the State Sanitary Code.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 239, § 8A, and cases such as Hemingway and Berman & Sons, sustained noncompliance with the State Sanitary Code regarding essential services (like heating) is treated as a serious breach of the landlord’s obligations and can support rent abatement and damages, underscoring that such failures also constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: In Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord’s failure over time to correct substantial violations of the State Sanitary Code may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss the State Sanitary Code or a pattern of failing to correct such violations. Instead, it holds that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct and that a statutory violation (here, the lead paint statute) alone is not enough. While the court favorably cites prior cases where failure to repair known defects violated § 14, this case itself does not hold that a landlord’s failure over time to correct substantial State Sanitary Code violations constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless in disregarding his tenant’s rights, and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’”}

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: In Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977), the Supreme Judicial Court held that a landlord’s “interference” with quiet enjoyment need not be intentional or in bad faith; it is enough that the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s actions or inactions is a serious interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly rejects any requirement that the landlord act with intent to deprive the tenant of quiet enjoyment and instead focuses on whether serious interference was the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct or omissions. The court emphasizes that “the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,” and applies that standard to find a breach of quiet enjoyment based on conditions the landlord created and could control, even though the landlords did not intend the interference.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: "Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.... There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.... Although some of our opinions have spoken of particular action or inaction by a landlord as showing a presumed intention to evict, the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling."

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: In Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994), the Court reaffirmed that a landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14, when the landlord’s conduct or failure to act results in substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, including where there are persistent unsafe or unhealthy conditions.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court squarely addressed G.L. c. 186, § 14 and reversed summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim, holding that if pervasive criminal/drug activity in common areas so limits tenants’ use of the premises, and the landlord fails to take reasonable measures within its control to address it, that can constitute a breach. The opinion characterizes such conditions as a “serious interference” substantially impairing the tenancy and ties potential liability to what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, thereby supporting liability where persistent unsafe or unhealthy conditions substantially interfere with quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be… liable… The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas… then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies… and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: In Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994), the Court recognized that housing conditions violating the State Sanitary Code can form the basis for claims against a landlord, including claims related to habitability and quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly involves and affirms tenant counterclaims for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and breach of quiet enjoyment, but it does not frame those claims specifically in terms of violations of the State Sanitary Code. The court discusses ‘deplorable conditions’ and ‘decent, safe and sanitary’ housing and measures habitability damages by the value of the premises as warranted, yet it does not say that State Sanitary Code violations, as such, form the basis for habitability or quiet-enjoyment claims. Thus, the proposition adds a Sanitary Code component that this opinion does not expressly articulate.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “The judge rendered a written decision in Wideman’s favor concluding, among other things, that conditions in her apartment had been in breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and that the value of the apartment had been reduced by fifty per cent… It is, after all, the tenant who suffers when conditions in an apartment violate the implied warranty of habitability… A private landlord, like Cruz Management, is not shielded from liability to which the landlord would otherwise be exposed merely because a part of its income is derived from Federal subsidy funds.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: In Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979), the Supreme Judicial Court held that violations of the State Sanitary Code can constitute a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, and that rent abatement and damages may be appropriate where the landlord fails to remedy code violations, particularly those involving essential services such as heat.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties the implied warranty of habitability to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and treats substantial Sanitary Code violations (here, loss of heat and hot water) as material breaches of that warranty. It affirms a rent abatement and damages award based on those conditions, and it emphasizes that lack of landlord fault or reasonable repair efforts does not bar rent abatement once the landlord has notice. Although the case builds on Hemingway, it clearly recognizes Code violations involving essential services as breaches of the implied warranty, justifying rent abatement and damages.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for…. The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water…. We read the Code to imply that civil remedies for violations are available during the landlord’s time to repair.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: In Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), the Court recognized the implied warranty of habitability in residential tenancies and held that serious defects that violate the State Sanitary Code may justify rent abatement and related relief.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: Even though this is a concurring/dissenting opinion, the author expressly states agreement with the majority that the traditional rule of no implied agreement of fitness must be reconsidered and that the court’s opinion makes the landlord’s repair obligations and the tenant’s rent obligations mutually interdependent, with rent liability limited to the reasonable value of the premises considering State Sanitary Code violations. That aligns with the proposition that the case recognizes an implied warranty of habitability in residential tenancies and allows rent abatement based on serious Sanitary Code defects. The concurring/dissenting judge primarily disputes the breadth and framing of the majority’s new warranty, not that such a warranty and rent abatement are recognized in this case.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The situation before us is that tenants who have admittedly withheld payment of rent for apartments which they continued to occupy despite alleged violations of the Code now take the position that by reason of the violations the landlord may neither evict them nor recover any rent from them. The opinion of the court holds that the tenants are subject to eviction because of their failure to pay rent, but that their liability for unpaid rent is limited to the reasonable value, if any, of their apartments, considering the alleged violations of the Code. … I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule … that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair….’”}

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions—including, by analogy, cases such as Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002), and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982)—make clear that where landlord conduct or neglect causes substantial disturbances, unsafe conditions, or persistent interferences, a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion is about commercial leases, constructive eviction, and the adoption of mutually dependent covenants—not about the statutory/lease covenant of quiet enjoyment in the sense described in the proposition. The court actually holds that the landlord’s failures did NOT amount to a constructive eviction or a breach making the premises untenantable, and instead grants relief under contract (dependent covenants) principles. While the court discusses constructive eviction cases that do involve substantial interferences, Wesson itself does not hold that such disturbances or unsafe conditions here violated quiet enjoyment; it finds the evidence legally insufficient for constructive eviction and does not rest its holding on quiet enjoyment doctrine.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “However, not every act or failure to act on the part of the landlord that causes disruption to a tenant rises to the level of a constructive eviction. To constitute a constructive eviction, the act must have ‘some degree of substance and permanence of character.’ … Thus, a landlord’s failure to provide a service that is essential to the use and enjoyment of the demised premises may qualify as a constructive eviction. Yet, conduct that does ‘not make the premises untenantable for the purposes for which they were used’ will not constitute constructive eviction.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts appellate decisions—including, by analogy, cases such as Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002), and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982)—make clear that where landlord conduct or neglect causes substantial disturbances, unsafe conditions, or persistent interferences, a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment is violated.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely treats repeated flooding and unsanitary conditions caused by the landlord’s failure to maintain the premises as an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and ties that conclusion to the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court explains that “quiet enjoyment” encompasses serious interferences with the tenancy (acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the premises) and holds Gem liable under § 14 for allowing repeated flooding that interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment. That directly supports the proposition that substantial disturbances and unsafe or unsanitary conditions can violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”
